decision_conditions: Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, the windows at first floor level in the western elevation serving the study and the ensuite attached to bedroom 4 shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with and permanently retained in obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, privacy screening, 1.7m in height as measured from the floor level adjacent to the screen, shall be erected along the western sides of the balconies and/or terraces. Aside from essential fixings, the screen(s) shall be constructed entirely of obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no additions or enlargements to any dwellinghouse(s) on the site (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) shall be erected unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no detached buildings (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) shall be erected on the site unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Any external lighting installed at the site shall be angled so as to prevent any spillage or glare beyond the site's boundaries.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, a sustainable drainage strategy and associated detailed design, management and maintenance plan for surface water drainage at the site using SuDS methods shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved drainage system shall be implemented in accordance with the approved sustainable drainage strategy prior to the beneficial occupation of the development and permanently retained thereafter.Reason: To prevent the development from increasing the risk of flooding to the site itself or elsewhere, in accordance with policy 5.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in accordance with BS5837: 2012 "Trees in relation to Design, Demolition and Construction". The approved measures shall be implemented prior to commencement of any work on site and maintained to the reasonable satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority until the completion of the development.Reason: To safeguard trees worthy of retention and in the interests of the character and appearance of the area, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any above ground works, a landscaping scheme shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following substantial completion of the development. The tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced during the following planting season, and the areas shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of waste and recycling facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The refuse and recycling facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of secure cycle parking facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.The cycle parking facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The flat roof elements of the proposed development hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The application site is located to the north of Berrylands and is currently occupied by a two storey detached residential dwelling with forecourt parking to the front and a rear garden. 26 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposal and 1 objection was received, making the following comments: Object to further extensionsPlanning History22/00420/FUL - Demolition of existing dwelling and erection of two storey replacement dwelling with rooms in loft space and new vehicle crossover - Granted 18.10.202221/02407/FUL - Erection of two storey dwellinghouse (following demolition of existing house), provision of 1no. extra car parking space and refuse/recycling store - Refused 26.10.2021. Appeal withdrawnThe key areas of assessment are:Principle of DevelopmentDesign Impact on neighbour amenityOther matttersPrinciple of DevelopmentThe current application is made pursuant to Section 73A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns applications to develop land without conditions previously attached. While this is, in effect, a fresh application for the entire development, the principle of the development has nevertheless already been established.On such an application, the local planning authority may only consider the conditions subject to which permission should be granted. It would therefore be unnecessary and unreasonable to revisit every issue which was relevant to the determination of the original application, unless varied through the proposal.In assessing the application, officers are mindful of any changes in planning policy or site circumstance since the granting of the original permission.Design and CharacterPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officers Comment: The proposal is for a change to the rear ground floor part of the building. Previously, this part of the building stepped away from the adjoining neighbours with a flat roof at a height of 3.3m. The proposal now extends to the boundary at a consistent depth but the height has been reduced to 3m.The amended design does not diminish the design quality of the overall development and is therefore in accordance with Policy D3 of the London Plan (2021), Policies CS8, DM 10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and Residential Design Guide SPD (2013).Standard of accommodationPolicy D6 of the London Plan 2021 sets out the standards for new housing within London, in terms of overall gross internal area ("GIA"), built-in storage space, bedroom sizes and ceiling heights. Housing development should be of high quality design and provide adequately-sized rooms, with comfortable and functional layouts which are fit for purpose and meet the needs of Londoners without differentiating between tenures. Policy DM13 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 states that the Council will expect proposals for new residential development to demonstrate that the scheme has been designed to provide adequate internal space appropriate to the intended number of occupants.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 requires developments to provide adequate private and/or communal amenity space. Policy Guidance 13 of the Residential Design SPD requires new residential dwellings to provide 50sqm of private garden per family house (+ 5sqm per extra bedroom over three) where the prevailing character of the area allows.Policy D12 of the London Plan requires all developments to achieve the highest standards of fire safety.The overall floorsapce of the building has increased slightly but, otherwise, there are no changes that would affect or diminish the overall standard of accommodation. Neighbour AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer's comment: The proposal now extends to the boundary with adjoining neighbours but the height at the boundary has been reduced by 300mm to 3m. With regard to No. 37 Berrylands, the plans indicate a neighbour extension considered through 22/03915/FUL. This application was refused and so no weight is given to this and the existing building line will be used to calculate the assessment. The proposed building extends approximately 3.3m beyond the rear building line of this neighbour. Given this limited depth, and the reduced height of 3m, this is not considered overbearing for this neighbour. With regard to No. 41 Berrylands, the proposed building extends approximately 5m beyond the rear building of this neighbour. Given the proposed building is set in from the neighbour boundary by approximately 0.8m, and the height has been reduced to 3m, the overall change in comparison  to the previous scheme is not considered to an impact that would be overbearing for this neighbour. Officers have undertaken a BRE daylight assessment (45 degree test) based on the proposed drawings and drawings the Council has for the neighbouring No. 37 Berrylands. No drawings are available for No. 41 Berrylands but an estimate (but reliable) assessment can be made based on site photos (indicating bifold doors to the neighbouring building) and the proposed drawings. Given this neighbouring building is set in from the neighbour boundary (as is the proposed building) and has bifold doors, it is evident that the proposed building would not interrupt the 45 degree line at a height of 1.6m. With regard to No. 37 Berrylands, it appears evident that the proposed building (which extends practically to the boundary) would also not interrupt the 45 degree line to the mid-point (at a height of 1.6m) of the neighbouring large double doors. On this basis, it can reasonably be concluded that the proposal would not result in an undue loss of daylight and sunlight to neighbours. In summary, the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy, subject to conditions. The proposal is in accordance with Policy DM 10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and Residential Design Guide SPD (2013).ConditionsSome of the conditions attached to 22/00420/FUL have been approved/discharged but all other conditions can be re-attached to this permission. Overall the development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and as such, planning permission is recommended for approval, subject to the conditions listed above.

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2012.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises a residential dwelling.Consultation No response received AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Other matters A condition requiring a fire safety strategy/statement is required in order for the development to accord with policy DM12 of the London Plan 2021ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

Application SiteThe application site consists of a semi-detached two storey single dwellinghouse The surrounding area is predominately residential in character. The site is located within The Groves Conservation Area and within Flood Zone 1.ProposalErection of single storey side and rear extension, rear dormer extension  and changes to fenestrationConsultation15 neighbouring properties were notified of the proposed development. In addition, a site was displayed near the site and a press notice published in the Surrey Comet.  One  representation has been received raising no objections subject to materials matching existing and that rooflights are conservation style rooflights.Maldens and Coombe Conservation Areas Advisory Committee: The application does not have a design and access statement. However, no objection subject to conditions that all rooflights are conservation style roof lights and that materials match existing.Trees and Landscapes Officer: I have no objection to the proposals which have no impact upon trees or landscape in the Conservation Area.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; The impact of the proposed development on heritage assets; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of and and buildings; - Fire Safety DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey side/rear extension would 'wrap around' the existing two storey rear addition and would have a maximum projection of 3m from the rear most wall of the house. The roof would be pitched, measuring 2m to the eaves at the lowest point near the boundary with No.65. Matching materials are proposed. There would be very limited visibility of the extension from the street, however, it would not appear obtrusive or detract from the character and appearance of the host building or surrounding area. The rear dormer roof extension would be of a sympathetic design, and size that would sit comfortably within the rear roof slope. Views of it would be limited to the rear elevation, as such, owing to its design and siting, it would be a sympathetic addition to the host building. The roof lights are acceptable in principle, however, officers agree with the representations received that they should be 'conservation style' which could be secured via conditions. Heritage AssetsSection 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.In determining planning applications which affect heritage assets, Paragraph 197 of the NPPF 2021 requires local planning authorities to take account of the desirability of sustaining and enhancing the significance of heritage assets and putting them to viable uses consistent with their conservation, the positive contribution that conservation of heritage assets can make to sustainable communities including their economic vitality, and the desirability of new development making a positive contribution to local character and distinctiveness.According to Paragraph 206, local planning authorities should look for opportunities for new development within conservation areas and within the setting of heritage assets in order to enhance or better reveal their significance. Proposals that preserve those elements of the setting that make a positive contribution to the asset (or which better reveal its significance) should be treated favourably.Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals affecting heritage assets, and their settings, should conserve their significance, by being sympathetic to the assets' significance and appreciation within their surroundings. The cumulative impacts of incremental change from development on heritage assets and their settings should also be actively managed. Development proposals should avoid harm and identify enhancement opportunities by integrating heritage considerations early on in the design process.At the local level, Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 set out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area.Designation summaryThe special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as: A planned mid-Victorian estate of houses of various sizes and styles, the core of which forms the Spring Grove Estate, including St John's Church, a school, and local shops.Officers consider that the proposed single storey side and rear extensions, rear dormer roof extension and roof lights (subject to conditions) would not materially detract from the appearance of the building or the immediate surrounding area. It follows, therefore, that Officers conclude there would be no harm to the significance of the Groves Conservation Area. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  Given the distance of the proposal to neighbouring habitable room windows at No. 61, no concerns are raised with regards to the impact on this property. With regards to the attached dwellinghouse at No.65, the proposed single storey side/rear extension would project approximately 6.7m along the shared boundary with this property, however, the extension would have a modest height of 2m to the eaves, with roof sloping away from the rear windows of the adjoining house. As such, the extension is not considered to have a significant adverse impact on the occupiers of this dwellinghouse by way of loss of daylight/sunlight.  There would be no adverse impacts to the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers as a result of the rear dormer or roof lights. In summary, owing to the relationship of the proposed extensions to surrounding residential properties, they are not expected to have any adverse impacts on the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy which suitably meets the requirements of Policy D12(A) of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalErection of single storey side/rear extensionThis application follows recently refused application 22/03722/HOU dated 23.01.2023 for the erection of single storey side/rear extension which was refused for the following reasons;1. By reason of its scale and depth, the proposed single storey rear/side extension, would adversely impact the amenities of the neighbouring property at no. 20 Selwyn Road, by reason of an unacceptable overbearing impact, increase in the sense of enclosure and loss of outlook to the adjoining property at no. 20 Selwyn Road. The proposal is therefore contrary to policies D3 of the London Plan 2021, policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.2. By reason of its scale and depth, the proposed single storey rear/side extension, would adversely impact the amenities of the neighbouring property at no. 20 Selwyn Road, by reason of the loss of daylight and direct sunlight to the adjoining property at no. 20 Selwyn Road. The proposal is therefore contrary to policies D3 of the London Plan 2021, policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.3. The porch extension would not relate well to the host property and appear as an incongruous addition within the streetscene. The proposal would have an unacceptable impact on the character and appearance of the host building and streetscene, contrary to the Council's Residential Design SPD, Policies D3 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012.These reasons for refusal would need to be addressed in order for this application to be successful. It is noted that the porch has been removed from the design so reason 3 for refusal falls away.ConsultationSeven neighbouring properties have been notified and two letters of objection have been received stating;- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inappropriate design/layout- Loss of light/SunlightThese material considerations will be considered as part of the assessment.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of and buildings; and,- Fire safety.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: It is noted that reasons 1 and 2 for refusal refer to the impact on amenity. The proposed rear extension has been reduced in depth. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: The proposed extension has been reduced in depth along the boundary with No. 20 Selwyn Road and No. 24 Selwyn Road and would now be compliant with BRE Guidance in relation to loss of daylight/sunlight. It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy and the previous reason for refusal falls away.Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through condition.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Schedule 10 of the legal agreement dated 29 July 2022 states:The Developer covenants with the Council:1 Not to demolish Piper Hall until the Temporary Facility Details have been submitted to and agreed by the Council.2 To provide the Temporary Facility in accordance with the approved Temporary Facility Details with the aim of making it available prior to the demolition of Piper Hall if this is reasonably practicable.3 To provide the New Facility within Phase 1 of the Development.4 Prior to Occupation of the New Facility to submit and obtain the approval of the Council to the Community Facility Management Plan to the Council5 Only to operate the New Facility in accordance with the approved Community Facility Management Plan.This application has been submitted pursuant to obligation 1, above. The applicant proposes to utilise the existing Queen Mary Hall (QMH )which is an existing community facility located in Cambridge Gardens, north of Cambridge Road Estate. The building has not been used since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic in March 2020. It is hoped that QMH will be available for future use after the new community centre is delivered in the Cambridge Road Estate regeneration providing a long term legacy benefit to the local community.QMH occupies circa 112 sqm whereas Piper Hall occupies approximately 200 sqm, therefore the interim facility would not be a like-for-like replacement, however, officers recognise that this option would carry sustainability benefits by allowing an underutilised building, within close proximity of the CRE to not only be brought back into use but also allow refurbishment of the building to secure its longevity.  Notwithstanding, this would be a temporary state of affairs until the replacement facility is delivered and the existing facility is considered to be an adequate interim solution.

Consultations: Neighbour notifications: No representations have been received. Historic England: Authorise delegated determination. No views expressed on the proposal.Kingston Town CAAC: Objection, regarding quality of proposed materiality/finishes. Concerns are also raised regarding lack of information regarding illumination.Site and Surroundings The site comprises a three storey mid terrace building located on the west side of Market Place. The site contains a Grade-II Listed Building and is located within the Kingston Old Town Conservation Area. The site also falls within the Kingston Town Centre Area of Archaeological Significance and Flood Risk Zone 2.Proposal This listed building consent application seeks consent for the replacement of 3nos existing individual letter facia signs and 2nos existing projecting signs.It is noted that a separate application for advertisement consent has been submitted to, and approved by, the Local Planning Authority (application reference: 23/00141/ADV). Planning Considerations The key planning considerations in this case are: - The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area (including heritage impact); and- The impact of the development on highway safety Character and Appearance / Impact upon Heritage AssetsThe NPPF states that the creation of high quality buildings and places is fundamental to what the planning and development process should achieve. Good design is a key aspect of sustainable development, creates better places in which to live and work and helps to make development acceptable to communities. Planning decisions should ensure that developments: will function well and add to the overall quality of the area; are visually attractive as a result of good architecture, layout and appropriate and effective landscaping; are sympathetic to local character and history; and establish a strong sense of place. Permission should be refused for development of poor design that fails to take opportunities available for improving the character and quality of an area and the way it functions, taking into account and local design standards or style guides in plans or supplementary planning documents. Conversely, where the design of a development accords with clear expectations in plan policies, design should not be used by the decision-maker as a valid reason to object to development. At the regional level, the London Plan requires that development have regard to the form, function and structure of an area, place or street, as well as the scale, mass and orientation of surrounding buildings. It should improve an area's visual or physical connection with natural features. In areas of poor or ill-defined character, development should build on the positive elements that can contribute to establishing an enhanced character for the future function of the area. Architecture should make a positive contribution to a coherent public realm, streetscape and wider cityscape. It should incorporate the highest quality materials and design, appropriate to its context. Accordingly, the Core Strategy states the Council's intention to protect the primarily suburban character of the Borough, its existing buildings and areas of high quality and historic interest from inappropriate development. The Council will seek opportunities for sensitive enhancement in these areas and in areas of poorer environmental quality, where character has been eroded or needs improving. The assessment of development proposals will be guided by the Borough Character Study and the Residential Design SPD, ensuring that new development: - Recognises distinctive local features and character - Has regard to the historic and natural environment - Helps enhance locally distinctive places of high architectural and urban design quality - Accords with neighbourhood "strategies for delivery" set out under "Character, Design and Heritage" - Relates well and connects to its surroundings The most essential elements identified as contributing to the character and local distinctiveness of a street or area which should be respected, maintained or enhanced include the following: - Prevailing development typology, including housing types, sizes and occupancy - Prevailing density of the surrounding area- Scale, layout, height, form (including roof forms) and massing - Landscape setting and features - Plot width and format, which includes spaces between buildings - Building line build-up, set-back and front boundary - Typical details and key features such as roof forms, window format, building materials and design detailing of elevations, existence of grass verges, etc. The Council's Residential Design SPD provides further in-depth guidance. Policy Guidance 29 (Materials and Detailing) states that: - Developers will be expected to demonstrate that they have considered the choice of materials and design detailing of those buildings that they consider represent the prevailing character of the streetscene or local area. - A preference should be given to the use of prevailing materials and details used in the surrounding local area unless it can be demonstrated that the choice of materials or use of design features in a proposal for residential development would enhance the character and appearance of the streetscene. - Care should be taken to ensure the replication of detailing or materials present in the street scene of local area represents an authentic synthesis of local architectural styles that compliment those of the host building or surrounding area. Development proposals which include the use of materials or detailing which is out of context or is lacking in imagination or character will be discouraged. NPPF provisions: It is one of the core principles of the NPPF that heritage assets should be conserved in a manner appropriate to their significance. Chapter 16 of the National Planning Policy Framework, 2021 at para 195 sets out that the local planning authority should identify and assess the particular significance of any heritage asset... They should take this assessment into account when considering the impact of a proposal on a heritage asset, to avoid or minimise conflict between the heritage asset's conservation and any aspect of the proposal. Paras 194-198 sets out the framework for decision making in planning applications relating to heritage assets and this application takes into account the relevant considerations in these paragraphs. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and policy 1.1 of the Council's Adopted Development (or Core) Strategy, (Core Strategy), and policy 7C of the Council's Adopted Development Management Development Plan Document, (DPD), seek to ensure that new development conserves the significance of heritage assets. Development should be sympathetic in its materials and architectural detailing and the introduction of designs or materials which undermine the significance of heritage assets should be avoided. More broadly, policies D4 and D8 of the London Plan 2021 collectively seek to ensure that new development is informed by and complements its surroundings. When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.Historic England's listing record sets out (No 6 - 9 Market Place): "Chiesman's Store (formerly Hide's Store). A large modern department store, most of which is not of interest, but it contains some items of importance. In the basement, some flint walling and C17 brickwork. Inside the store, a fine mid C17 timber staircase from the Castle Hotel, which formerly occupied the site. Heavy square newels with carved, panelled sides and ball finials; strings carved with laurel leaves; heavy, moulded handrails; the space between handrails and strings filled with heavy foliage and roses, within which are some human figures. Some of the newels are initialled. [VCH]. Also incorporated into the new structure is an C18 hipped, tiled roof above a much-altered 3 storey, 4 bay range. [On the south side facing alleyway to back yard]."The application proposes the replacement of 3x existing individual letter facia signs and 2x existing projecting signs. The signage would be non-illuminated and comprise the retailer's name in individual vinyl lettering in uppercase letters ("NEXT"). The two projecting signs would have a black background with white lettering and the 3no. fascia signs would have black lettering against white timber boarding and stone background.While Officers note the concerns raised by the KCAAC, Officers take into consideration that the proposed signage would be very similar to that which presently exists in terms of style and materiality. It is considered that, when compared to the existing signage, the proposed signage would preserve the character and appearance of the Kingston Old Town Conservation Area and the Grade-II listed building. Highway SafetyThe NPPF requires that in assessing applications for development, it is ensured that: appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport modes can be - or have been - taken up; safe and suitable access to the site can be achieved for all users; and any significant impacts from the development on the transport network (in terms of capacity and congestion), or on highway safety, can be cost effectively mitigated to an acceptable degree. Development should only be prevented or refused on highways grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or the residual cumulative impacts on the road network would be severe. Local Planning Authorities are expected to have regard to its effect upon the safe use and operation of any form of traffic or transport on land (including the safety of pedestrians), on or over water, or in the air. Public safety considerations, the second arm of control over advertisements, do not arise very frequently. However, when it can be shown that signs would be confused with traffic signals or the visibility of drivers is impaired, a solid and sustainable ground for refusal of Advertisement Regulation consent is provided. Officers consider that the non-illuminated proposals (as stated in the accompanying advert consent) would not be significantly different from the existing situation and would therefore have no adverse impact upon highways and transportation, thereby complying with Core Strategy Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012.Conclusion The proposed development would provide for the display of advertisements to the ground floor commercial unit at 8 -9 Charter Quay, Market Place, Kingston. The proposed signage is found to be acceptable, preserving the character and appearance of the designated Grade-II listed building, and the wider Kingston Old Town Conservation Area. The proposals would not have any material effect on highway safety. The proposal would be acceptable and would preserve the character and appearance of the Grade-II Listed Building and Conservation Area, having due regard to Section 16 of the Planning (Listed Building and Conservation Area) Act 1990 permission should be granted. Recommendation That listed building consent should be GRANTED.
